reviewText: Boy oh boy oh boy.Finally!It's here,glad to have this.Take'n me back toto good'ol dayz,when this was on vhs(wooo!).Had it then,now have it on disc.The dvd has some x-tra fun to go with it.4 x-tra trax,one neverreleased on cd(album)-"walk away".WOW!this song alone is worth having.Ifyour a die hard dokken fan,BUY THIS !BUY IT NOW !.It's also cool to seedon and mick during their interview.Just wish the guys could settle theirdifferences and get back to original form.Oh well at least we can watchthis over and over.

reviewText: If you are a fan of 80's metal, then Dokken was probably near the top of your list.  This is a great DVD of thier home video release Unchain The Night, a long time coming, and worth the wait.  This contains the original 7 videos Into the fire, Just got luck, breaking the chains, alone again, the hunter, In My Dreams, and It's not Love sandwiched between goofy shots of the band behind the scenes.  Bonus videos include Walk Away, Dream Warriors, Heaven Sent, and Burning Like A Flame, all surrounded by intro's from Don Dokken and Mick Brown.  Also their is a 30 minute video of Don and Mick reminiscing about the Video, the past, and what the future holds for dokken.  The quality of transfer is good, and well worth the investment for 80's fans.  Sure, the style of big hair and spandex is dated, but the songs remain great.
summary: Nice transfer to DVD, with bonus features

Title: N/A

reviewText: What more can be said of videos with singer in a komono chained to a bed, the horrible jagged edges around pand member images of the cheap key effect in "In My Dreams", and the AC/DC rip off of the band playing on the flat bed truck.  Love how they drive by the WIGS store, Don's second home.  The videos show how Dokken tried to copy and follow every video trend that came along, never quite doing it right.  The interviews with Mick are a scream, he tells hysterical stories, most at his expense.  Don however seems to have an old man's failing memory or is just full of crap.  Don state Dokken only did one live album, "Beast in the East" forgeting the easily forgettable "Live in Japan 1996", "Live from the Sun" and "One Live Night".  Don claims that no one including Dokken aficinados ever heard the song "Liar" even though Liar is the last song on the widely available "Back in the Streets" bootleg.  Don also gives more crap about "the new Dokken album returns to the classic Dokken souns" knowing full well that the new album is more faux grunge lite.  I like how Don's wears a goofy skull hat so he didn't have to bother putting his wig on, or maybe he realizes how fake it looks on tv.  Mick still looks good like he did in the 80's, however Don looks really, really old and haggard, like his own grandad.
summary: Cheezy Videos, Great Interview, Old Man's Failing Memory

reviewText: By far one of the best, if not the best hair bands to come out of the 80's, these videos really brought back memories for me as a teenager in the 80's, Don Dokken's writing style is un-matched in my opinion, you don't get songs like this written today by today's artist, there is some highlights of their tour overseas in 1986, there isn't much more I can say that hasn't already been said, but if you want a trip back in time to when songs meant somthing, then this is for you..
summary: A DVD for every "Dokken" fan out there...

reviewText: Being a big fan of Dokken and hair metal,this was a definite buy.I purchased it at a great price,of course at Amazon.If you love Dokken,you know the tunes and the videos. "Alone Again","In My Dreams","Just Got Lucky","Dream Warriors" are all here plus the other great songs.Great commentary on the four songs by Don & Mick. Glad to see Mick still with Dokken and the new album coming out this year. Too bad Lynch couldn't get in good graces,but what the heck.Highly recommended to the die hard Dokken fans and just hair metal lovers out there.

reviewText: This is an absolutely fantastic DVD. I highly recommend it for anyone who remotely loves Dokken (or doesn't know them but enjoys '80s music). My mom, sister, and I had a blast last night watching it for the first time. Any of those studio videos you've seen on YouTube, they're included. Nothing is missing. But there's an added bonus for those of you who splurge and get this, instead of relying solely on the Internet. In between every video, there's candid footage shot with the band's Super 8 and mini interviews. There's a whole layer of personality to these guys that you don't see (often) in the music videos. It all comes out on this DVD. I think Don Dokken and Jeff Pilson especially shine in the personality dept. Don always looks so serious when he's singing; behind the scenes, we find out he likes old '60s sitcoms and has a sense of humor about things. In concert, Jeff looks like a crazy rocker without a brain in his head; in person, he's actually quite thoughtful and calm.Another nice thing about this collection is how you don't have to worry about language. Anytime someone swears in the candid moments, they're "bleeped" out. Even then, there isn't a ton of cussing, so it's not like you're hearing that beeping noise every other minute (unlike TruTv). The only thing I don't like on this entire DVD is the video for "Into the Fire." It's one of those freaky '80s videos with far-too-flexible girls in leather. But I just skip that vid and it's no problem. Other than that, I'm completely satisfied with this collection. It has everything: great music, well-executed camera work, funny dialogue, and (if you're in the mindset of my sisters) cute guys to shriek over. So why are you still sitting here reading this? Haven't I convinced you? Go order this so you can be Rokken with Dokken!
